steps.title: Welcome
steps.content:
Welcome to Digital Logic

In this tutorial you will build fundamental logic circuits step by step, using the Digital simulator running live in your browser.

The simulator is on the right. You can:

  • Add components from the component tree (left side of Digital)
  • Draw wires by clicking and dragging between pins
  • Right-click components to edit their properties
  • Press the Play button (or Space) to start the simulation
Each step has a Load Checkpoint button at the bottom. Click it to load the completed circuit for that step if you get stuck or want to skip ahead.

Use the Prev/Next buttons above, or the arrow keys, to navigate steps.

steps.title: Step 1: AND Gate
steps.content:
The AND Gate

An AND gate outputs 1 only when all inputs are 1.

Truth Table

ABY
000
010
100
111

Build It

  1. From the component tree, find Logic → And and place it
  2. Add two Input components (I/O → In) and label them A and B
  3. Add one Output component (I/O → Out) and label it Y
  4. Wire the inputs to the AND gate, and the gate output to Y
  5. Press Space to start the simulation, then click the inputs to toggle them

Verify the truth table matches!

steps.title: Step 2: Half Adder
steps.content:
The Half Adder

A half adder adds two single-bit numbers. It produces a sum bit and a carry bit.

The Circuit

A half adder uses:

  • An XOR gate for the sum (S = A ⊕ B)
  • An AND gate for the carry (Cout = A · B)

Truth Table

ABSCout
0000
0110
1010
1101

Build It

  1. Start with your AND gate from Step 1 (or load the checkpoint)
  2. Add an XOR gate (Logic → XOr)
  3. Connect both inputs A and B to both gates
  4. Add a second output labeled Cout for the carry
  5. Label the XOR output as S for sum
Tip: You can branch a wire by clicking on an existing wire and dragging to create a junction.

steps.title: Step 3: SR Latch
steps.content:
The SR Latch — Memory!

So far our circuits have been combinational — the output depends only on the current inputs. An SR latch is our first sequential circuit: it can remember a value.

How It Works

An SR latch uses two cross-coupled NOR gates:

  • S (Set): setting S=1 forces Q=1
  • R (Reset): setting R=1 forces Q=0
  • When both S=0 and R=0, the latch holds its previous value
  • S=1 and R=1 simultaneously is the forbidden state

Build It

  1. Place two NOR gates (Logic → NOr)
  2. Cross-couple them: the output of each NOR feeds back to an input of the other
  3. Add inputs S and R
  4. Add outputs Q and ~Q
When you start the simulation, try: Set S=1 briefly (Q goes high), then release. Q stays high — the latch remembers! Then pulse R=1 to reset.

This is the fundamental building block of all digital memory — flip-flops, registers, and eventually RAM are all built from this concept.

steps.title: Next Steps
steps.content:
What's Next?

You've built the three foundational circuit types:

  1. Basic gate (AND) — the building block of all logic
  2. Combinational circuit (Half Adder) — combining gates for arithmetic
  3. Sequential circuit (SR Latch) — adding memory to logic

Ideas to Explore

  • Full Adder: Extend the half adder with a carry input (Cin)
  • D Flip-Flop: Add a clock to the SR latch for synchronous operation
  • 4-Bit Counter: Chain D flip-flops to count in binary
  • ALU: Build an arithmetic logic unit that can add, subtract, AND, and OR

Digital has a rich component library — explore the tree on the left to discover multiplexers, decoders, registers, RAM, and even a built-in processor!

You can save your circuits using File → Save (they persist in your browser's storage). Use File → Export to download a .dig file you can share or submit.
